newsitem.title: INDIA: Rice - Asian exporters seal large sales contracts.
newsitem.headline: Rice - Asian exporters seal large sales contracts.

text.p: Asia's leading rice exporters have recently locked in a slew of large sales contracts, but prices are seen coming under pressure in the region as the major Indian harvest gets underway, traders said on Thursday.
Indian companies have signed forward contracts to export nearly 300,000-400,000 tonnes of rice from the new crop in November, they said.
"Around 300,000-400,000 tonnes of forward rice export contracts have been signed for November shipments," said an official in a leading Delhi foodgrains export firm.
India's winter rice harvest has started in the northern states of Punjab, Haryana and Uttar Pradesh. Harvesting in the other states would start within a week, traders said.

"This can be the moving period for Indian rice exports but prices are still ruling higher than Vietnam prices, so Indian rice is not competitive," said an official in another Delhi foodgrains export firm.
"Indian prices are not friendly vis-a-vis Vietman rice export prices," said one exporter.
Traders said Indian five percent long grain non-Basmati rice was quoted at around $290 a tonne FOB, 10 percent at $280, 15 percent at $255 and 25 percent at $240.
"The (rice) crop this winter would be a normal one," said the exporter.

However, traders said rice export contracts will not substantially pick up until the final harvest production is known by late November. "Nothing can be said now. We have to wait and watch," the official said.
Industry officials and traders had earlier said India's winter rice production is expected to be marginally higher than last year's winter output of 71 million tonnes.
The winter harvest starts early in October and continues until late in November. India harvests two rice crops, getting the bulk of its output from the winter crop.
Major buying orders from Indonesia and Hong Kong helped brighten up a dull Thai rice market which has been in a lull recently, traders said on Thursday.
But prices remained mostly steady as exporters bought just enough rice to cover their immediate needs.
Thai benchmark 100 percent grade B rice was quoted around $320-$340 a tonne, barely changed from last week. Prices of lower grade rice, however, eased slightly.
Traders see more orders coming in November and December when fresh supply is expected to pull the prices down and make Thai rice attractive.
"I know I said this before but I will say it again. The prices at the moment are a bit expensive. Buyers will wait a bit before entering the market again," one trader said.
"The prospects are still good. Exports this year will meethe said.
Hong Kong rice importers signed a memorandum of understanding last week with Thai rice exporters to buy 270,000 tonnes of high quality rice in 1997.
The Thai government also this week approved a counter trade deal between Thailand and Indonesia.
Under the agreement, Indonesia will buy 110,000 tonnes of various grades of Thai rice for delivery between November and February while Thai will buy two aircraft from Indonesia.
"Besides those orders, there are some small orders from our regular customers like Singapore, the United States and Malaysia," said another trader.
In Vietnam, export rice prices have softened over the last week in dull trade with dealers seeing little immediate prospect of a change in the situation.
Traders in Ho Chi Minh City and elsewhere in Indochina said five percent broken grade was trading at around $265 a tonne FOB Saigon Port, down slightly from around $275 last week.
"New harvests are appearing in places like Iran and the Philippines. So demand seems to be tailing off in quite a few places," one said.
Dealers added that floods affecting Vietnam's Mekong Delta had had little impact on rice so far, thanks to early harvesting.
Vietnam's Saigon Giai Phong newspaper reported on Thursday that farmers had rushed to transport rice to Ho Chi Minh City for export ahead of the Mekong Delta floods.
The paper said the resultant excess supply had contributed to the current drop in prices.
WORLD RICE PRICES IN U.S. DOLLARS/TONNE: Oct 10 Oct 3
Thailand-100 pct white B benchmark FOB Bangkok 320-340 325-340
India-25 pct broken(non-Basmati long grain)FOB 240 235
India-15-10 pct broken FOB (west coast port) 255-280 250-275
Vietnam-5.0 percent broken FOB Saigon port 265-270 276-280
Vietnam-10 percent broken FOB Saigon port 255-260 265-270
U.S.-California medium grain ($ per cwt) 20.00-21.00 20.00-21.00 U.S.-Long grain Arkansas ($ per cwt) 20.50-21.50 20.50-21.50
